author: Cheyenne Roundtree For Dailymail.com
title: Pit bull owner slams animal shelter for euthanizing dog
text:
A woman is heartbroken after a Las Vegas animal shelter euthanized her beloved pit bull less than 30 minutes after he arrived at the facility.
Michelle Smith, 22, was shocked to learn that her dog named Trouble was euthanized by Lied Animal Shelter after her pet was hit by a car on Sunday in Las Vegas.
The animal had been in the care of the shelter not even 30 minutes before staff decided to put down Trouble because he had a broken leg and was 'suffering'.
Michelle Smith, 22, (left) was heartbroken after her pit bull Trouble (right) was put to sleep by a Las Vegas animal shelter only 30 minutes after he was brought to the facility on Sunday
Smith is furious with Lied Animal Shelter and questions the staff's decision of the euthanasia because Trouble was pictured moments before his death looking 'fine' despite having a broken leg (above)
Trouble had escaped from a yard where he was being kept at while Smith was in the process of moving and was he hit by a car when he ran into traffic.
Las Vegas Animal Control picked up the injured dog and brought him to the shelter where it was determined he had 'a broken leg, head trauma, multiple lacerations, significant bruising and suspected internal injuries', the Review Journal reported.
The shelter then decided it was best to put down down the dog in a 'humane euthanasia' because he was in pain and 'suffering', Smith said.
She questions the severity of Trouble's injuries because she was provided with a photo of her pet just minutes before he was put to sleep, pictured seemingly 'fine'.
Smith said her pet, who she has had for the past four years, was her best friend and like a child to her
The shelter said Trouble had 'a broken leg, head trauma, multiple lacerations, significant bruising and suspected internal injuries' after he was hit by a car
Smith said Trouble looked 'fine' and later added: 'Is my dog going to die from a broken leg? Are you freaking kidding me?'
She said in a Facebook post: 'They said he has two broken legs and he was suffering but my question is if he has two broken legs and is suffering so bad how does he have enough energy to stand? He looks fine?'
The foundation has a requirement that it is supposed to hold healthy animals brought in for at least 72 hours but a spokeswoman for the Lied Animal Shelter said there is not a policy in place for injured animals.
Kate Whiteley explained to the Review Journal: 'Without owner contact information we have to rely on the expert opinion of the veterinary staff to make a decision in the best interest of the animal.'
Smith is not happy with that explanation and severely doubts her dog's injuries warranted his death.
She said to KTNV : 'Is my dog going to die from a broken leg? Are you freaking kidding me?
She added: 'You didn't even give my dog 24 hours, you didn't even give my dog 24 minutes.'
The foundation released a statement that said because Trouble didn't have a microchip and they were not able to contact his owner, they decided it was best to put him down.
Smith said she was planning to get Trouble a microchip implant but insists he was wearing tags when he was picked up by animal control.

The foundation released a statement that said they were sympathetic to Smith's loss
